To verify the superiority of Mn-Fe dual-component doped catalysts in terms of deNOx performance, the differences of mechanisms in selective catalytic reduction with ammonia (NH3-SCR) between Fe/γ-Al2O3 and Mn-Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were investigated by using the density functional theory (DFT). On the surface of the Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, the NH2 group generated by NH3 dehydrogenation can react with NO and NO2 to form NH2NO and NH2NO2, respectively. The decomposition process of NH2NO is established as the rate-determining step in the reaction between NH3 and NO, while the rate-determining step in the reaction between NH3 and NO2 is the decomposition of NHNO2. Mn doping significantly enhances the catalyst's adsorption performance for O2 and oxidation ability toward NO, thereby promoting the production of NO2. Additionally, Mn doping markedly reduces the reaction barriers, facilitating the dissociation of NH2NO and NHNO2 on the Mn-Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. These findings may elucidate the reasons of the effective enhancement of deNOx performance in the Mn-doped Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, which establishes a foundation for the subsequent development and application of Mn-Fe bimetallic-doped SCR deNOx catalysts. Introduction As the primary energy source used in industrial production, fossil fuels emit a lot of nitrogen oxides (NOx) during combustion. The NOx not only cause diverse environmental issues including acid rain, photochemical smog formation, and depletion of the ozone layer [1–3], but also gravely threaten human health [4]. Therefore, controlling NOx emissions has become one of the most pressing issues to be addressed urgently. To solve the problems caused by NOx emissions, many countries have put forward various NOx removal technologies to limit NOx emissions [5]. The selective catalytic reduction with ammonia (NH3-SCR) has become one of the most effective means of reducing NOx emissions [6]. Vanadium-based catalysts supported on TiO2 are the most used commercial SCR catalysts due to their outstanding NOx removal rate and excellent N2 selectivity. In general, the removal efficiency of NOx can reach 80–90 % in the temperature range of 250–450 °C [7]. However, vanadium-based catalysts have flaws, such as a narrow high-activity temperature window and poor performance at low temperatures. In addition, they cause a potential biological hazard because many vanadium ions trapped in the human body will form the accumulation of vanadium ions in tissues, endangering human health [8–10]. Therefore, looking for a green and highly active low-temperature NH3-SCR catalysts have become an urgent problem. γ-Al2O3 has abundant acidic sites and a large specific surface area. It can decrease the loading of active ingredients, thus reducing preparation costs. Therefore, the deNOx catalysts loaded on γ-Al2O3 are the focus of research [11–14]. Metal oxides such as Mn-based, Ce-based, and Fe-based oxides are widely used as additives for NH3-SCR catalysts due to their excellent redox properties [15–21]. In particular, Mn-based catalysts can be used as bifunctional catalysts for the simultaneous removal of both NO and CO pollutants [22,23], but more N2O is generated during the NH3-SCR reaction [24,25]. Not only that, the flue gas may contain a substantial quantity of H2O and SO2, which can result in a decline in the deNOx efficiency of metal oxide catalysts or cause complete deactivation [26,27]. The bimetallic modification can avoid this problem because of the synergism between the modified components. Therefore, two-component or multi-component doped catalysts have received increasing attention in recent years, such as Mn-Ce, Mn-Fe, Co-Al, Mn-Ce-Fe, and Sm-Mn-Fe catalysts [28–33]. However, the reaction mechanism of two-component or multi-component catalysts is still unclear and requires further research. This study utilizes the density function theory (DFT) to explore the reaction mechanism of the Fe/γ-Al2O3 and Mn-Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalysts in the deNOx process. Specifically, the study focused on the adsorption characteristics of NH3, NO, and O2 on the catalyst surface. And the configuration changes and energy changes of NH3 and NO, NH3 and NO2 intermediates during the reaction were studied. The results furnish a theoretical foundation for comprehending the reaction mechanism of bifunctional sites and offer insight into identifying more efficient deNOx catalysts. Theory and computational details Calculation method All calculations were based on the density function theory (DFT). Spin polarization calculations generalized gradient approximation generalization (GGA) and the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) function were used for calculations [34]. The projector augmented wave (PAW) method was utilized to solve the Kohn-Sham equations [35], while the Climbing-Image Nudged Elastic Band (CI-NEB) method was adopted to compute the reaction pathways of gas molecules on the catalyst surfaces [36]. To gain a better understanding of the adsorption properties of gas molecules on the catalyst surfaces, the quantity of electron transfer ( Q ) was obtained by Bader charge calculations [37], which is shown in the Eq. (1): (1) Q = Z v a l − Q b a d e r where Q b a d e r and Z v a l represent Bader charge and valence electron of atoms, respectively. In addition, the molecule adsorption was compared by calculating the energy of adsorption ( E ads ) through the Eq. (2). (2) E a d s = E s u r f a c e + g a s − ( E s u r f a c e + E g a s ) where E s u r f a c e + g a s represents the total energy when the gas is adsorbed on the catalyst surface, E s u r f a c e represents the energy on the catalyst surface, and E g a s represents the energy of gas molecules. The stability of the doped structure and the complexity of the formation process can be determined by the binding energy [38]. The E dop was obtained by the Eq. (3). (3) E d o p = E x − d o p + N * μ x − ( E c h u + N * μ c h u ) where E x − d o p represents the energy of the doped catalyst, E c h u denotes the energy of the catalyst before doping, μ x and μ c h u represent the energy of the doping atom and the energy of the replaced atom, respectively, and N represents the number of doping atoms. In the chemical reaction, the disparity in energy between the reactants and the transition state is called the reaction barrier ( E b ) [39], which was obtained by the Eq. (4). (4) E b = E ( T S ) − E ( I S ) where E ( T S ) and E ( I S ) refer to the total energy of the transition state (TS) and the initial state (IS), respectively. Surface model The structure of γ-Al2O3 adopts the crystal model proposed by Digne et al. [40], with lattice parameters of a = 5.587 Å, b = 8.413 Å, c = 8.068 Å; α = γ = 90°, β = 90.59°, as shown in Fig. 1 (a). Before optimizing the γ-Al2O3 model, the optimal cut-off energy and K-point parameters should be determined through convergence testing calculations. As shown in Fig. 2 , the convergence is achieved at cut-off energy and K-points of 450 eV and 3 × 3 × 3, respectively. Therefore, a larger cut-off energy of 500 eV and 4 × 4 × 4 K-points were chosen for more precise DFT calculations. During structural optimization and energy calculations, the convergence criteria for atomic forces and energy were set at 0.05 eV/Å and 10−5 eV, respectively. According to previous studies [41,42], the γ-Al2O3 (110) surface is the most easily exposed. Therefore, the reaction mechanism studied was carried out on the surface of γ-Al2O3 (110). As illustrated in Fig. 1(b). In molecular structure optimization, the Monkhorst-Pack (MP) method utilizing the Brillouin zone is employed for numerical integration. To eliminate the effect of surface interactions in the mean direction, a layer of the vacuum of 15 Å was added in the z-axis orientation. To eliminate the effect of stress on the asymmetrical surface, a dipole moment correction was performed [43]. Fe/γ-Al2O3 model In this study, the Fe/γ-Al2O3 (110) model was developed through the substitution of atoms with Fe on the Al sites over the γ-Al2O3 surface. It is not fair to compare the active site with a single Fe center to the active site with both Fe and Mn functional groups. To avoid differences in performance due to the number of active sites, the configurations were constructed as shown in Fig. 3 . The configuration with the lowest energy is shown in Fig. 3(b). Therefore, the subsequent calculation of the reaction mechanism of NOx on the catalyst surface is based on Fig. 3(b). Mn-Fe/γ-Al2O3 model To comprehensively investigate the impact of Mn doping on the performance of Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalysts for NOx removal, a model was developed to simulate the co-doping of Mn and Fe. These models were established by replacing surface Fe atoms with Mn atoms on the Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, as shown in Fig. 4 . The configuration of Fig. 4(a) has the lowest energy among the configurations studied, suggesting that it is the most stable configuration and is likely the most representative of the actual catalyst under the given conditions. Therefore, it would be appropriate to use the configuration of Fig. 4(a) as the catalyst model to further investigation into the reaction mechanism of NOx on the catalyst surface. Results and discussion Adsorptive characteristics of NH3, NO, and O2 on the Fe/γ-Al2O3 and Mn-Fe/γ-Al2O3 surfaces To investigate the deNOx mechanisms of Fe/γ-Al2O3 and Mn-Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, a thorough understanding of the surface adsorption capability of the catalysts for gas molecules such as NH3, NO, and O2 is imperative. The adsorption energy, which is the amount of energy released when a molecule is adsorbed on the surface, is typically used as a basis for evaluation. Many studies have shown that NH3 and NO molecules usually form adsorption products by N-terminal binding to the active sites on the surfaces of catalysts [44–46]. O2 can adsorb to the catalyst surface via its O atom end, forming adsorbed oxygen. Based on these studies, the adsorption tendencies of NH3, NO, and O2 molecules on the Fe/γ-Al2O3 and Mn-Fe/γ-Al2O3 surfaces were calculated and the results are illustrated in Fig. 5 . Meanwhile, to further investigate the adsorption mechanism of gas molecules on the active site, their partial density of states (PDOS) and crystal orbital Hamiltonian population (COHP) on the chemical adsorption sites were investigated, and the results are presented in Fig. 6 . Adsorptive characteristics of NH3 on the Fe/γ-Al2O3 and Mn-Fe/γ-Al2O3 surfaces In the standard NH3-SCR reaction, NH3 molecules are preferentially adsorbed on the catalyst surface, followed by a dehydrogenation reaction to produce NH2. The generated NH2 reacts with NO to form N2 and H2O [47,48]. Therefore, studying the performance of NH3 absorption on the catalyst surface can provide a better understanding of the deNOx reaction. The (a), (d), (g), and (j) configurations depicted in Fig. 5 represent the surface adsorption of NH3 on the Fe/γ-Al2O3 and Mn-Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. Based on the illustration, on the surface of the Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, NH3 has a greater tendency to adsorb on the Fe2 site, with an adsorption energy of −1.56 eV, and the corresponding Bader charge change is 0.24 e. For the Mn-Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, the adsorption energy of NH3 on the Mn site increases slightly to −1.61 eV, with a charge change of 0.22 e. The PDOS results in Fig. 6(a) and (d) reveal that in the energy range between −10 eV and −3 eV, there are strong hybridization peaks, indicating a significant interaction between N and Mn atoms. According to the corresponding COHP results, the bonding contribution of the Fe-N bond is highly significant at the energy level of approximately −6 eV. This larger peak area is likely the primary reason for the higher adsorption energy of NH3 on the Fe2 site. Following the adsorption of NH3 on the Mn site of the Mn-Fe/γ-Al2O3, the bonding orbital peak area of spin electrons at the −5 eV level is roughly equivalent to the orbital area formed by NH3 on the Fe2 site of the Fe/γ-Al2O3. Furthermore, the absolute value of ICOHP for spin-up electrons increases (1.36→1.39), while the absolute value of ICOHP for spin-down electrons remains unchanged (1.41→1.41). This indicates an increased contribution of spin-up electrons to the N-Mn bond, which is one of the reasons for the slight enhancement of NH3 adsorption due to the co-doping of Mn and Fe. Adsorptive characteristics of NO on the Fe/γ-Al2O3 and Mn-Fe/γ-Al2O3 surfaces Under catalysis, NO molecules acting as the main components in low-temperature deNOx, usually involve in the NH3-SCR reaction in three forms: (1) adsorbed on the catalyst surface as single molecules of NO to form different forms of nitrite; (2) combined with NH2 precursors formed after dehydrogenation reaction with NH3 to form NH2NO intermediates; (3) oxygen adsorbed on the catalyst surface oxidizes to produce NO2. The conformations of Fig. 5(b), (e), (h), and (k) illustrate the adsorption behavior of NO molecules on the Fe/γ-Al2O3 and Mn-Fe/γ-Al2O3 surfaces. Based on the adsorption structure, it is clearly shown that NO molecules can form single-dentate nitroso groups through N atoms with Fe and Mn sites on the catalyst surface. On the surface of the Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, the adsorption energies of NO on the Fe1 and Fe2 sites are similar, but it tends to be adsorbed on the Fe1 site, with adsorption energies and electronic changes of −2.98 eV and +0.11 e, respectively. On the Mn-Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalyst surface, the adsorption energy of NO on the Mn and Fe sites exhibits a significant difference, with the adsorption energy and electronic change on the Fe site reaching −2.88 eV and +0.17 e. As depicted in Fig. 6(b) and (e), after NO forms stable adsorption on the catalyst surface, multiple hybridization peaks are formed between the N-p orbitals and Fe-d orbitals, indicating a strong interaction between N and Fe after NO adsorption. In the COHP plot, some peaks below the Fermi level have large y-coordinate values, indicating the formation of strong bonding orbitals between N and Fe, especially where the electron contribution to bonding is greatest for the hybridized orbitals at −13 eV. After NO adsorption on the Fe site of the Mn-Fe/γ-Al2O3, the peak area of the bonding orbitals at −13 eV remains unchanged, but there is a reduction in the peak area between −9 eV and −7 eV. This result is mainly due to the lower adsorption energy of NO on the Mn-Fe/γ-Al2O3 compared to the Fe/γ-Al2O3. Simultaneously, the absolute value of ICOHP for spin-up electrons increases (4.07→4.21), while the absolute value of ICOHP for spin-down electrons decreases (4.39→4.13). This indicates an increased contribution of spin-up electrons to bonding and a decreased contribution of spin-down electrons to bonding. However, the overall absolute value of ICOHP decreases, which is also a result of the weakening of NO adsorption under the influence of Mn. Adsorptive characteristics of O2 on the Fe/γ-Al2O3 and Mn-Fe/γ-Al2O3 surfaces The O2 molecules play a crucial role in the NH3-SCR reaction, mainly by oxidizing NO and NH3 molecules, thus accelerating the rate of the deNOx reaction. It not only combines with NO to form NO2 precursors, but also reacts with NH3 molecules to form NH2 and OH species [49,50]. The conformations (c), (f), (i), and (l) depicted in Fig. 5 illustrate the adsorption behavior of O2 on the catalyst surfaces. O2 molecules can bind to the Fe1 and Mn sites in the Fe/γ-Al2O3 and Mn-Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, respectively, forming adsorbed oxygen species, and the corresponding adsorption energies are −2.13 eV and −2.43 eV, and they gain 0.34 e and 0.31 e electrons from the two catalyst surfaces. As shown in Fig. 6(c) and (f), PDOS results indicate the presence of many hybridization peaks below the Fermi level, suggesting that O2 can form the stable chemical adsorption on the surfaces of both catalysts. According to the COHP results, when O2 adsorbs on the Mn-Fe/γ-Al2O3 surface, the peak area of the bonding orbitals significantly increases. Simultaneously, the absolute values of ICOHP for both spin-up and spin-down electrons increase substantially (3.37→3.56, 2.98→3.64). Therefore, under the influence of Mn, the bond strength of O-Mn increases significantly, leading to a greatly enhanced adsorption of O2. NO oxidation property Based on existing studies [51–53], it has been found that on the catalyst surface, the generation of NO2 through the reaction between NO and O2 can enhance the rate of the deNOx reaction. This is mainly because the generation of NO2 is a key factor for the rapid SCR reaction. Consequently, promoting the generation of NO2 is considered an effective strategy for improving the overall performance of SCR catalysts. Therefore, studying the reaction behavior of NO oxidation to NO2 on the catalyst surface has become crucial. As illustrated in Fig. 7 (a), NO combines with O2 that is adsorbed on the Fe1 site to form a single-tooth nitrate. During the adsorption process, NO and O2 release 1.09 eV of energy and form a stable structure. At the same time, the O-O bond between the adsorbed oxygen changes from the initial length of 1.27 Å to 1.39 Å, indicating a tendency to break the O-O bond upon combining with NO. Subsequently, the ONO2 configuration (IS) undergoes decomposition and transforms into NO2 by overcoming an energy barrier of 0.60 eV. Comparing the energies of the initial state (IS) and the final state (FS), it is determined that the conversion of ONO2 into NO2 on the Fe/γ-Al2O3 surface is an exothermic process, releasing 1.36 eV of energy. Fig. 7(b) shows the oxidation process of NO on the Mn-Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalyst surface. The gaseous NO and adsorbed O2 form the initial structure (IS1) by releasing an energy of 0.78 eV. Then gaseous NO2 is formed through the transition state (TS1). The energy barrier for this decomposition process is relatively low, which is 0.47 eV. During the decomposition, the N-O bond formed by the combination of the N atom from NO with the O atom from O2 elongates from 1.39 Å to 1.52 Å. In comparison with the NO oxidation process by the Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, the Mn-Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalyst oxidizes NO to NO2 more easily. This suggests that the incorporation of Mn and Fe as dual active components in the catalyst enhances the NO oxidation capability. Reaction mechanism on the Fe/γ-Al2O3 and Mn-Fe/γ-Al2O3 surfaces Reaction of NH3 and NO on the Fe/γ-Al2O3 and Mn-Fe/γ-Al2O3 surfaces The CI-ENB method was used to study the reaction pathways of NH3 and NO on the catalyst surfaces, and the results are depicted in Fig. 8 . The reaction pathway primarily comprises six steps: (1) NH3 adsorption; (2) NH3 dehydrogenation; (3) NH2NO generation; (4) NH2NO dissociation; (5) H2O generation; (6) H2O and N2 desorption. When an NH3 molecule adsorbs on the catalyst surface, it can form the ligand ammonia. The ligand ammonia can undergo a dehydrogenation reaction to produce an amino group. The presence of the amino group is essential for further binding to NO to form nitrosamines, which are necessary intermediates in the SCR reaction [54]. Fig. 8Ⅰ(a, b) presents the dehydrogenation process of NH3 on the Fe/γ-Al2O3 surface. When gaseous NH3 adsorbs on an Fe2 atom, 1.56 eV of energy is released. Next, the N-H bond in NH3 dissociates, causing the H atom to move closer to the nearby O atom, extending their distance from 1.02 Å to 1.65 Å. In the process of H atom captured by the O atom, it must surpass an energy barrier of 1.74 eV to establish the OH group. On the surface of the Mn-Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, after NH3 adsorbs on the Mn site, overcoming an energy barrier of only 0.87 eV is required to reach the TS' state. Moreover, on the surface of the Mn-Fe/γ-Al2O3, the dehydrogenation reaction releases more energy (0.52 eV > 0.02 eV). This indicates that on the Mn-doped surface of Fe/γ-Al2O3, dehydrogenation reactions are more likely to occur, which is favorable to the formation of amino and nitrosamines. As depicted in Fig. 8Ⅰ, the gaseous NO combines with NH2 to form the important intermediate NH2NO, and this process releases 0.53 eV of energy. The structures (c-d) illustrate the change in the NH2NO adsorption configuration, with a relative energy decrease of 0.77 eV. The Fe-N bond shortens from 2.05 Å to 1.83 Å, indicating that the configuration (d) is more stable. In the configuration (d), NH2NO forms Fe-O and Fe-N bonds by binding to the Fe1 and Fe2 sites through the O and N atoms of NO, respectively. In the process from the structure (d) to (e), the adsorbed NH2NO dissociates into N2, OH groups, and an H atom, with a reaction barrier of 2.29 eV. In the transition structure TS1, the N-H bond undergoes cleavage, with one H atom adsorbing on an O atom on the Fe/γ-Al2O3 surface, and the other H atom bonding to the O atom in the NH2NO structure. Subsequently, the N-O bond extends (1.30 Å → 1.67 Å), indicating a tendency to break and form an OH group. In the subsequent process (e-f), the H atom produced by NH3 dehydrogenation combines with the OH group to form H2O, adsorbed on the Fe1 site. The energy coordinate reveals that the reaction between the OH group and the hydrogen atom releases 0.16 eV of energy. Finally, NH2NO completes the decomposition process, N2 and H2O are desorbed sequentially, and the energy barriers to be overcome are 0.96 eV and 0.94 eV, respectively. Fig. 8Ⅱ shows the reaction pathway and configuration of NH3 and NO reactions on the Mn-Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalyst surface. NO reacts with NH2 to form a stable NH2NO structure, such as the configuration (l), and releases 1.08 eV of energy. The structures (l-m) reveal the decomposition process of NH2NO, which is similar to the process of NH2NO decomposition on the Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. In this process, an H atom forms an OH group by bonding with the surface oxygen atom of the Mn-Fe/γ-Al2O3, while the other H atom bonds with the O atom in the NH2NO structure, forming an OH group and adsorbing on the Fe site. The decomposition process releases 2.42 eV of energy. In the structure (m-n), the OH groups combine with the H atom previously dissociated by NH3 to form H2O. This process requires overcoming the reaction barrier of 0.32 eV. Subsequently, N2 and H2O are desorbed sequentially, corresponding to the energy barriers of 0.72 eV and 0.93 eV, respectively. From the reaction pathway of NH3 and NO, it can be observed that NH2NO decomposition requires high energy on the surfaces of both catalysts, indicating that the decomposition of NH2NO determines the reaction rate between NH3 and NO. On the catalyst surface after Mn doping, the energy barrier for NH2NO decomposition is lower (1.59 eV < 2.29 eV). Moreover, by comparing the reaction energy diagrams of the two catalysts in the process of NH3 and NO reactions, it is found that the total activation energy barrier of the Mn-Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalyst is lower than that of the Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. This suggests that the dual doping of Mn and Fe promotes the reaction between NH3 and NO, thereby enhancing the deNOx activity of the catalyst. Reaction of NH3 and NO2 on the Fe/γ-Al2O3 and Mn-Fe/γ-Al2O3 surfaces In the NH3-SCR reaction, NO2 exhibits the strong adsorption on the catalyst surfaces, making it relatively easy to react with NH3, thereby achieving a high NOx conversion rate through the fast SCR reaction [5]. Therefore, the reaction pathways of the two were further studied, and the results are shown in Fig. 9 , mainly consisting of five steps: (1) NH2NO2 generation; (2) NHNO2 generation; (3) NHNO2 dissociation; (4) H2O desorption; (5) N2O dissociation. Fig. 9Ⅰ illustrates the energy changes of NH3 and NO2 during the reaction process on the surface of the Fe/γ-Al2O3. The configuration (a-b) indicates that an H atom separates from the NH3 molecule and combines with the adsorbed O atom to form the OH radical. The energy required to overcome the dehydrogenation process is 0.52 eV. In this reaction, the energy needed for NH3 dehydrogenation is much lower than that in the NH3-NO reaction, indicating that, in the presence of NO2 and O sites, the N-H bond of NH3 is more easily activated, forming NH2 species. Subsequently, the liberated NH2 combines with NO2 to produce the NH2NO2 intermediate. In the following steps (b-c), NH2NO2 dehydrogenates to produce NHNO2, overcoming a 0.66 eV energy barrier. In this process, one N-H bond of NH2NO2 extends from 1.02 Å to rupture, and the liberated H atom combines with the OH radical to form H2O. This step is an exothermic process, with an energy absorption of 0.33 eV. The structure (c-d) illustrates the further dissociation of the NHNO2. In the decomposition process of NHNO2, overcoming a 1.45 eV energy barrier is required for the activation of N-H and N-O bonds, ultimately forming N2O species. The transition state (TS2) reveals the breaking of the N-H bond in the NHNO2 intermediate, with an elongation of the N-O bond length and a tendency for rupture. This process releases 1.67 eV of energy. Subsequently, the formed H2O desorbs from the catalyst surface, absorbing energy of 0.98 eV. After H2O desorption, N2O binds to the Fe1 site, forming a Fe-O bond with a length of 2.13 Å. Reaction energy coordinates show that the adsorption energy of N2O is −0.70 eV, lower than the adsorption energies of NH3, NO, and O2, indicating that N2O adsorption cannot dominate the SCR deNOx reaction. The transition state (TS3) reveals the breaking of the N-O bond in N2O, and this decomposition process overcomes a 0.73 eV energy barrier, releasing 0.65 eV of heat. After the release of N2, one adsorbed O atom and one OH group remain on the Fe/γ-Al2O3 surface. Among them, the formed OH group can act as a Brønsted acid site to promote the L-H mechanism on the catalyst surface. The oxygen atom has the capacity to bind with gaseous NO, giving rise to NO2 species and thus re-initiating the NH3-SCR reaction. From the energy coordinates of the NO2-NH3 reaction in Fig. 9, it can be seen that the dissociation of NHNO2 requires more energy, indicating that this process serves as the rate-determining step (RDS) controlling the overall reaction rate of NH3 and NO2. Fig. 9(h–n) illustrates the reaction between NH3 molecules and Fe-NO2 and Mn-O structures, and the reaction path is like Fig. 9(a–g). This reaction also requires overcoming four transition states (TS', TS1′, TS2′, TS3′), with reaction barriers of 0.42, 0.41, 0.75, and 0.47 eV, respectively. In addition, the desorption of H2O in Fig. 9(k, l) is a larger endothermic process, absorbing energy of 1.28 eV. In summary, it is known that the dehydrogenation of the NHNO2 intermediate in this reaction path is also the step controlling the overall reaction rate. Compared to the reactions in Fig. 9 (a–g), the energy consumption for the formation, dehydrogenation, and further decomposition of the NH2NO2 intermediate on the Mn-Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalyst surface is lower than that on the Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalyst surface, indicating that the doping of Mn and Fe is more favorable for the reaction between NH3 and NO2 molecules. Conclusions The adsorption properties and reaction mechanisms of gas molecules on the surfaces of the Fe/γ-Al2O3 and Mn-Fe/γ-Al2O3 were analyzed by using the DFT method. Gas molecules NH3, NO, and O2 are prone to adsorption on the surfaces of the Fe/γ-Al2O3 and Mn-Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, forming coordinated ammonia, nitrite, and adsorbed oxygen. It is worth noting that the catalyst with Mn-Fe dual-component doping significantly enhances the adsorption performance of O2, thereby boosting the oxidative ability of NO, promoting the generation of NO2, accelerating the rapid SCR reaction, effectively improving the deNOx performance of the catalyst. Furthermore, Mn doping not only promotes the oxidative dehydrogenation of NH3, facilitating the formation of NH2 precursors, but also significantly reduces the decomposition barriers of the reaction-determining step NH2NO in the NH3+NO reaction pathway and the decomposition barrier of NHNO2 in the NH3+NO2 reaction pathway, contributing to the generation of N2 and H2O. The theoretical calculations in this study reveal the adsorption characteristics of gasses, the reaction pathways for NH3+NO and NH3+NO2, as well as the promotion mechanism of Mn doping on the microscopic molecular reactions on the Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalyst surface. This provides a foundation for the subsequent development and application of Mn-Fe bimetal-doped SCR deNOx catalysts. coredata.dc:description: To verify the superiority of Mn-Fe dual-component doped catalysts in terms of deNOx performance, the differences of mechanisms in selective catalytic reduction with ammonia (NH3-SCR) between Fe/γ-Al2O3 and Mn-Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were investigated by using the density functional theory (DFT). On the surface of the Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, the NH2 group generated by NH3 dehydrogenation can react with NO and NO2 to form NH2NO and NH2NO2, respectively. The decomposition process of NH2NO is established as the rate-determining step in the reaction between NH3 and NO, while the rate-determining step in the reaction between NH3 and NO2 is the decomposition of NHNO2. Mn doping significantly enhances the catalyst's adsorption performance for O2 and oxidation ability toward NO, thereby promoting the production of NO2. Additionally, Mn doping markedly reduces the reaction barriers, facilitating the dissociation of NH2NO and NHNO2 on the Mn-Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. These findings may elucidate the reasons of the effective enhancement of deNOx performance in the Mn-doped Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, which establishes a foundation for the subsequent development and application of Mn-Fe bimetallic-doped SCR deNOx catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Promoting mechanism of Mn doping on the NH3-SCR reaction over the Fe/γ-Al2O3 catalyst surface
